natural problem: Square $ABCD$ has area $200$. Point $E$ lies on side $\overline{BC}$. Points $F$ and $G$ are the midpoints of $\overline{AE}$ and $\overline{DE}$, respectively. Given that quadrilateral $BEGF$ has area $34$, what is the area of triangle $GCD$?
natural solution: We begin by drawing a diagram: [asy] size(5cm); pair a=(0,1); pair b=(1,1); pair c=(1,0); pair d=(0,0); pair e=(1,.82); pair f=(a+e)/2; pair g=(d+e)/2; fill(b--e--g--f--cycle,gray); fill(g--c--d--cycle,pink);

dot(a);dot(b);dot(c);dot(d);dot(e);dot(f);dot(g); draw(a--b--c--d--a); draw(a--e--d); draw(e--g--f--b); draw(g--c); label("$A$",a,NW); label("$B$",b,NE); label("$C$",c,SE); label("$D$",d,SW); label("$E$",e,E);

label("$F$",f,SW); label("$G$",g,NW); [/asy] We know that the gray area above (quadrilateral $BEGF$) has area $34$, and we wish to determine the pink area ($\triangle GCD$). First we note that $\triangle AED$ has base $AD$, equal to the side length of square $ABCD$, and also has height equal to the side length of square $ABCD$.

Thus $\triangle AED$ has area equal to half the area of $ABCD$, or $100$. Triangle $\triangle FEG$ has half the base and half the height of $\triangle AED$, so its area is $\frac12\cdot\frac 12\cdot 100 = 25$.

Since quadrilateral $BEGF$ can be divided into $\triangle FEG$ and $\triangle FBE$, we know that $\triangle FBE$ has area $34-25=9$. This is half the area of $\triangle ABE$ (which shares an altitude with $\triangle FBE$ and has twice the corresponding base).

Thus, $\triangle ABE$ has area $18$. Since square $ABCD$ can be divided into triangles $ABE$, $AED$, and $ECD$, we know that the area of $\triangle ECD$ is $200-100-18 = 82$. Finally, $\triangle GCD$ shares an altitude with $\triangle ECD$ and has half the corresponding base, so the area of $\triangle GCD$ is $\frac 12\cdot 82$, or $\boxed{41}$.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes ABCD BEGF GCD :: real
assumes h0 : "ABCD = 200"
and h1 : "BEGF = 34"
and h2 : "ABCD = BEGF + GCD + GCD"
shows  "GCD = 41"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Square $ABCD$ has area $200$. Point $E$ lies on side $\overline{BC}$. Points $F$ and $G$ are the midpoints of $\overline{AE}$ and $\overline{DE}$, respectively. Given that quadrilateral $BEGF$ has area $34$, what is the area of triangle $GCD$? The final Answer is 41
 ### Proof
 We begin by drawing a diagram: [asy] size(5cm); pair a=(0,1); pair b=(1,1); pair c=(1,0); pair d=(0,0); pair e=(1,.82); pair f=(a+e)/2; pair g=(d+e)/2; fill(b--e--g--f--cycle,gray); fill(g--c--d--cycle,pink);
 dot(a);dot(b);dot(c);dot(d);dot(e);dot(f);dot(g); draw(a--b--c--d--a); draw(a--e--d); draw(e--g--f--b); draw(g--c); label("$A$",a,NW); label("$B$",b,NE); label("$C$",c,SE); label("$D$",d,SW); label("$E$",e,E);
 label("$F$",f,SW); label("$G$",g,NW); [/asy] We know that the gray area above (quadrilateral $BEGF$) has area $34$, and we wish to determine the pink area ($\triangle GCD$). First we note that $\triangle AED$ has base $AD$, equal to the side length of square $ABCD$, and also has height equal to the side length of square $ABCD$.
 Thus $\triangle AED$ has area equal to half the area of $ABCD$, or $100$. Triangle $\triangle FEG$ has half the base and half the height of $\triangle AED$, so its area is $\frac12\cdot\frac 12\cdot 100 = 25$.
 Since quadrilateral $BEGF$ can be divided into $\triangle FEG$ and $\triangle FBE$, we know that $\triangle FBE$ has area $34-25=9$. This is half the area of $\triangle ABE$ (which shares an altitude with $\triangle FBE$ and has twice the corresponding base).
 Thus, $\triangle ABE$ has area $18$. Since square $ABCD$ can be divided into triangles $ABE$, $AED$, and $ECD$, we know that the area of $\triangle ECD$ is $200-100-18 = 82$. Finally, $\triangle GCD$ shares an altitude with $\triangle ECD$ and has half the corresponding base, so the area of $\triangle GCD$ is $\frac 12\cdot 82$, or $\boxed{41}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes ABCD BEGF GCD :: real
assumes h0 : "ABCD = 200"
and h1 : "BEGF = 34"
and h2 : "ABCD = BEGF + GCD + GCD"
shows  "GCD = 41"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: The area of square ABCD is 200. The area of square BEGF is 34. The area of square ABCD is equal to the sum of the areas of squares BEGF and two squares GCD. What is the area of square GCD? The final answer is 41.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "A (\<lambda>_. 200) = 200"
and h1 : "A (\<lambda>_. 34) = 34"
and h2 : "A (\<lambda>_. 41) = 41"
and h3 : "A (\<lambda>_. 200) = A (\<lambda>_. 34) + A (\<lambda>_. 41) + A (\<lambda>_. x)"
shows  "x = 125"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Square $ABCD$ has area $200$. Point $E$ lies on side $\overline{BC}$. Points $F$ and $G$ are the midpoints of $\overline{AE}$ and $\overline{DE}$, respectively. Given that quadrilateral $BEGF$ has area $34$, what is the area of triangle $GCD$? The final Answer is 41
 ### Proof
 We begin by drawing a diagram: [asy] size(5cm); pair a=(0,1); pair b=(1,1); pair c=(1,0); pair d=(0,0); pair e=(1,.82); pair f=(a+e)/2; pair g=(d+e)/2; fill(b--e--g--f--cycle,gray); fill(g--c--d--cycle,pink);
 dot(a);dot(b);dot(c);dot(d);dot(e);dot(f);dot(g); draw(a--b--c--d--a); draw(a--e--d); draw(e--g--f--b); draw(g--c); label("$A$",a,NW); label("$B$",b,NE); label("$C$",c,SE); label("$D$",d,SW); label("$E$",e,E);
 label("$F$",f,SW); label("$G$",g,NW); [/asy] We know that the gray area above (quadrilateral $BEGF$) has area $34$, and we wish to determine the pink area ($\triangle GCD$). First we note that $\triangle AED$ has base $AD$, equal to the side length of square $ABCD$, and also has height equal to the side length of square $ABCD$.
 Thus $\triangle AED$ has area equal to half the area of $ABCD$, or $100$. Triangle $\triangle FEG$ has half the base and half the height of $\triangle AED$, so its area is $\frac12\cdot\frac 12\cdot 100 = 25$.
 Since quadrilateral $BEGF$ can be divided into $\triangle FEG$ and $\triangle FBE$, we know that $\triangle FBE$ has area $34-25=9$. This is half the area of $\triangle ABE$ (which shares an altitude with $\triangle FBE$ and has twice the corresponding base).
 Thus, $\triangle ABE$ has area $18$. Since square $ABCD$ can be divided into triangles $ABE$, $AED$, and $ECD$, we know that the area of $\triangle ECD$ is $200-100-18 = 82$. Finally, $\triangle GCD$ shares an altitude with $\triangle ECD$ and has half the corresponding base, so the area of $\triangle GCD$ is $\frac 12\cdot 82$, or $\boxed{41}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes A :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "A (\<lambda>_. 200) = 200"
and h1 : "A (\<lambda>_. 34) = 34"
and h2 : "A (\<lambda>_. 41) = 41"
and h3 : "A (\<lambda>_. 200) = A (\<lambda>_. 34) + A (\<lambda>_. 41) + A (\<lambda>_. x)"
shows  "x = 125"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: In a set of numbers, the function $A$ assigns a value to each number. Given that $A(200) = 200$, $A(34) = 34$, and $A(41) = 41$, find the value of $x$ such that $A(200) = A(34) + A(41) + A(x)$. The final answer is $125$.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A :: "real \<Rightarrow> real" and B :: "real \<Rightarrow> real" and C :: "real \<Rightarrow> real" and D :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
and E :: "real \<Rightarrow> real" and F :: "real \<Rightarrow> real" and G :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "area_square A B C D = 200"
and h1 : "E \<in> closed_segment B C"
and h2 : "F = midpoint A E"
and h3 : "G = midpoint D E"
and h4 : "area_quad B E G F = 34"
shows  "area_triangle G C D = 41"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem

First we note that $\triangle AED$ has base $AD$, equal to the side length of square $ABCD$, and also has height equal to the side length of square $ABCD$.
 Thus $\triangle AED$ has area equal to half the area of $ABCD$, or $100$. Triangle $\triangle FEG$ has half the base and half the height of $\triangle AED$, so its area is $\frac12\cdot\frac 12\cdot 100 = 25$.
 Since quadrilateral $BEGF$ can be divided into $\triangle FEG$ and $\triangle FBE$, we know that $\triangle FBE$ has area $34-25=9$. This is half the area of $\triangle ABE$ (which shares an altitude with $\triangle FBE$ and has twice the corresponding base).
 Thus, $\triangle ABE$ has area $18$. Since square $ABCD$ can be divided into triangles $ABE$, $AED$, and $ECD$, we know that the area of $\triangle ECD$ is $200-100-18 = 82$. Finally, $\triangle GCD$ shares an altitude with $\triangle ECD$ and has half the corresponding base, so the area of $\triangle GCD$ is $\frac 12\cdot 82$, or $\boxed{41}$.

theorem
fixes A :: "real \<Rightarrow> real" and B :: "real \<Rightarrow> real" and C :: "real \<Rightarrow> real" and D :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
and E :: "real \<Rightarrow> real" and F :: "real \<Rightarrow> real" and G :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "area_square A B C D = 200"
and h1 : "E \<in> closed_segment B C"
and h2 : "F = midpoint A E"
and h3 : "G = midpoint D E"
and h4 : "area_quad B E G F = 34"
shows  "area_triangle G C D = 41"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: Given a square ABCD with an area of 200 square units, let E be a point on the closed segment BC. Let F be the midpoint of AE and G be the midpoint of DE. If the area of the quadrilateral BEGF is 34 square units, find the area of triangle GCD. The final answer is 41 square units.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A B C D E F G :: "real^2"
assumes h0 : "square A B C D"
and h1 : "area_triangle A B C = 200"
and h2 : "E \<in> closed_segment B C"
and h3 : "F = midpoint A E"
and h4 : "G = midpoint D E"
and h5 : "area_quadrilateral B E G F = 34"
shows  "area_triangle G C D = 41"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Square $ABCD$ has area $200$. Point $E$ lies on side $\overline{BC}$. Points $F$ and $G$ are the midpoints of $\overline{AE}$ and $\overline{DE}$, respectively. Given that quadrilateral $BEGF$ has area $34$, what is the area of triangle $GCD$? The final Answer is 41

 We begin by drawing a diagram: [asy] size(5cm); pair a=(0,1); pair b=(1,1); pair c=(1,0); pair d=(0,0); pair e=(1,.82); pair f=(a+e)/2; pair g=(d+e)/2; fill(b--e--g--f--cycle,gray); fill(g--c--d--cycle,pink);

First we note that $\triangle AED$ has base $AD$, equal to the side length of square $ABCD$, and also has height equal to the side length of square $ABCD$.
 Thus $\triangle AED$ has area equal to half the area of $ABCD$, or $100$. Triangle $\triangle FEG$ has half the base and half the height of $\triangle AED$, so its area is $\frac12\cdot\frac 12\cdot 100 = 25$.
 Since quadrilateral $BEGF$ can be divided into $\triangle FEG$ and $\triangle FBE$, we know that $\triangle FBE$ has area $34-25=9$. This is half the area of $\triangle ABE$ (which shares an altitude with $\triangle FBE$ and has twice the corresponding base).
 Thus, $\triangle ABE$ has area $18$. Since square $ABCD$ can be divided into triangles $ABE$, $AED$, and $ECD$, we know that the area of $\triangle ECD$ is $200-100-18 = 82$. Finally, $\triangle GCD$ shares an altitude with $\triangle ECD$ and has half the corresponding base, so the area of $\triangle GCD$ is $\frac 12\cdot 82$, or $\boxed{41}$.

theorem
fixes A B C D E F G :: "real^2"
assumes h0 : "square A B C D"
and h1 : "area_triangle A B C = 200"
and h2 : "E \<in> closed_segment B C"
and h3 : "F = midpoint A E"
and h4 : "G = midpoint D E"
and h5 : "area_quadrilateral B E G F = 34"
shows  "area_triangle G C D = 41"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: Given a square $ABCD$ with a triangle $ABC$ having an area of 200 square units, let $E$ be a point on the segment $BC$. Let $F$ be the midpoint of the segment $AE$ and $G$ be the midpoint of the segment $DE$. If the area of quadrilateral $BEFG$ is 34 square units, find the area of triangle $GCD$. The final answer is 41 square units.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A :: real
assumes h0 : "A = 200"
and h1 : "A = (area (square ABCD))"
and h2 : "E \<in> (BC)"
and h3 : "F = midpoint (AE)"
and h4 : "G = midpoint (DE)"
and h5 : "area (quadrilateral BEGF) = 34"
shows  "area (triangle GCD) = 41"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Square $ABCD$ has area $200$. Point $E$ lies on side $\overline{BC}$. Points $F$ and $G$ are the midpoints of $\overline{AE}$ and $\overline{DE}$, respectively. Given that quadrilateral $BEGF$ has area $34$, what is the area of triangle $GCD$? The final Answer is 41
 ### Proof
 We begin by drawing a diagram: [asy] size(5cm); pair a=(0,1); pair b=(1,1); pair c=(1,0); pair d=(0,0); pair e=(1,.82); pair f=(a+e)/2; pair g=(d+e)/2; fill(b--e--g--f--cycle,gray); fill(g--c--d--cycle,pink);

First we note that $\triangle AED$ has base $AD$, equal to the side length of square $ABCD$, and also has height equal to the side length of square $ABCD$.
 Thus $\triangle AED$ has area equal to half the area of $ABCD$, or $100$. Triangle $\triangle FEG$ has half the base and half the height of $\triangle AED$, so its area is $\frac12\cdot\frac 12\cdot 100 = 25$.
 Since quadrilateral $BEGF$ can be divided into $\triangle FEG$ and $\triangle FBE$, we know that $\triangle FBE$ has area $34-25=9$. This is half the area of $\triangle ABE$ (which shares an altitude with $\triangle FBE$ and has twice the corresponding base).
 Thus, $\triangle ABE$ has area $18$. Since square $ABCD$ can be divided into triangles $ABE$, $AED$, and $ECD$, we know that the area of $\triangle ECD$ is $200-100-18 = 82$. Finally, $\triangle GCD$ shares an altitude with $\triangle ECD$ and has half the corresponding base, so the area of $\triangle GCD$ is $\frac 12\cdot 82$, or $\boxed{41}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes A :: real
assumes h0 : "A = 200"
and h1 : "A = (area (square ABCD))"
and h2 : "E \<in> (BC)"
and h3 : "F = midpoint (AE)"
and h4 : "G = midpoint (DE)"
and h5 : "area (quadrilateral BEGF) = 34"
shows  "area (triangle GCD) = 41"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: In square ABCD with side length 200, point E is on side BC. Point F is the midpoint of AE, and point G is the midpoint of DE. The area of quadrilateral BEGF is 34. Find the area of triangle GCD. The final answer is 41.

theorem
fixes A B C D E F G :: "real^2"
assumes h0 : "is_square A B C D"

and h3 : "F = midpoint A E"
and h4 : "G = midpoint D E"
and h5 : "area_quadrilateral B E G F = 34"
shows  "area_triangle G C D = 41"

 Thus $\triangle AED$ has area equal to half the area of $ABCD$, or $100$. Triangle $\triangle FEG$ has half the base and half the height of $\triangle AED$, so its area is $\frac12\cdot\frac 12\cdot 100 = 25$.
 Since quadrilateral $BEGF$ can be divided into $\triangle FEG$ and $\triangle FBE$, we know that $\triangle FBE$ has area $34-25=9$. This is half the area of $\triangle ABE$ (which shares an altitude with $\triangle FBE$ and has twice the corresponding base).

Finally, $\triangle GCD$ shares an altitude with $\triangle ECD$ and has half the corresponding base, so the area of $\triangle GCD$ is $\frac 12\cdot 82$, or $\boxed{41}$.

theorem
fixes A B C D E F G :: "real^2"
assumes h0 : "is_square A B C D"
and h1 : "area_triangle A B C = 200"
and h2 : "E \<in> closed_segment B C"
and h3 : "F = midpoint A E"
and h4 : "G = midpoint D E"
and h5 : "area_quadrilateral B E G F = 34"
shows  "area_triangle G C D = 41"

  show ?thesis sledgehammer

If the area of quadrilateral $BEGF$ is 34 square units, find the area of triangle $GCD$. The final answer is 41 square units.

Finally, $\triangle GCD$ shares an altitude with $\triangle ECD$ and has half the corresponding base, so the area of $\triangle GCD$ is $\frac 12\cdot 82$, or $\boxed{41}$.

theorem
fixes A B C D E F G :: "real^2"
assumes h0 : "square A B C D"
and h1 : "area A B C D = 200"
and h2 : "E \<in> closed_segment B C"
and h3 : "F = midpoint A E"
and h4 : "G = midpoint D E"
and h5 : "area B E G F = 34"
shows  "area G C D = 41"

  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: Given a square ABCD with an area of 200 square units, let E be a point on segment BC, F be the midpoint of segment AE, and G be the midpoint of segment DE. If the area of quadrilateral BEGF is 34 square units, what is the area of triangle GCD? The final answer is 41 square units.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "A (square ABCD) = 200"

and h3 : "G = midpoint D E"
and h4 : "A (quadrilateral BEGF) = 34"

a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Square $ABCD$ has area $200$. Point $E$ lies on side $\overline{BC}$. Points $F$ and $G$ are the midpoints of $\overline{AE}$ and $\overline{DE}$, respectively. Given that quadrilateral $BEGF$ has area $34$, what is the area of triangle $GCD$? The final Answer is 41

 We begin by drawing a diagram: [asy] size(5cm); pair a=(0,1); pair b=(1,1); pair c=(1,0); pair d=(0,0); pair e=(1,.82); pair f=(a+e)/2; pair g=(d+e)/2; fill(b--e--g--f--cycle,gray); fill(g--c--d--cycle,pink);
 dot(a);dot(b);dot(c);dot(d);dot(e);dot(f);dot(g); draw(a--b--c--d--a); draw(a--e--d); draw(e--g--f--b); draw(g--c); label("$A$",a,NW); label("$B$",b,NE); label("$C$",c,SE); label("$D$",d,SW); label("$E$",e,E);
 label("$F$",f,SW); label("$G$",g,NW); [/asy] We know that the gray area above (quadrilateral $BEGF$) has area $34$, and we wish to determine the pink area ($\triangle GCD$). First we note that $\triangle AED$ has base $AD$, equal to the side length of square $ABCD$, and also has height equal to the side length of square $ABCD$.
 Thus $\triangle AED$ has area equal to half the area of $ABCD$, or $100$. Triangle $\triangle FEG$ has half the base and half the height of $\triangle AED$, so its area is $\frac12\cdot\frac 12\cdot 100 = 25$.
 Since quadrilateral $BEGF$ can be divided into $\triangle FEG$ and $\triangle FBE$, we know that $\triangle FBE$ has area $34-25=9$. This is half the area of $\triangle ABE$ (which shares an altitude with $\triangle FBE$ and has twice the corresponding base).
 Thus, $\triangle ABE$ has area $18$. Since square $ABCD$ can be divided into triangles $ABE$, $AED$, and $ECD$, we know that the area of $\triangle ECD$ is $200-100-18 = 82$. Finally, $\triangle GCD$ shares an altitude with $\triangle ECD$ and has half the corresponding base, so the area of $\triangle GCD$ is $\frac 12\cdot 82$, or $\boxed{41}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes A :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "A (square ABCD) = 200"
and h1 : "E \<in> segment BC"
and h2 : "F = midpoint A E"
and h3 : "G = midpoint D E"
and h4 : "A (quadrilateral BEGF) = 34"
shows  "A (triangle GCD) = 41"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: In quadrilateral $ABCD$ with area 200, let $E$ be a point on segment $BC$. Let $F$ be the midpoint of segment $AE$, and let $G$ be the midpoint of segment $DE$. If the area of quadrilateral $BEFG$ is 34, find the area of triangle $GCD$. The final answer is 41.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A B C D E F G :: "real^2"
and area :: "(real^2) \<Rightarrow> (real^2) \<Rightarrow> (real^2) \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "area A B C = 200"
and h1 : "area B E G F = 34"
and h2 : "F = midpoint A E"
and h3 : "G = midpoint D E"
shows  "area G C D = 41"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Square $ABCD$ has area $200$. Point $E$ lies on side $\overline{BC}$. Points $F$ and $G$ are the midpoints of $\overline{AE}$ and $\overline{DE}$, respectively. Given that quadrilateral $BEGF$ has area $34$, what is the area of triangle $GCD$? The final Answer is 41
 ### Proof
 We begin by drawing a diagram: [asy] size(5cm); pair a=(0,1); pair b=(1,1); pair c=(1,0); pair d=(0,0); pair e=(1,.82); pair f=(a+e)/2; pair g=(d+e)/2; fill(b--e--g--f--cycle,gray); fill(g--c--d--cycle,pink);
 dot(a);dot(b);dot(c);dot(d);dot(e);dot(f);dot(g); draw(a--b--c--d--a); draw(a--e--d); draw(e--g--f--b); draw(g--c); label("$A$",a,NW); label("$B$",b,NE); label("$C$",c,SE); label("$D$",d,SW); label("$E$",e,E);
 label("$F$",f,SW); label("$G$",g,NW); [/asy] We know that the gray area above (quadrilateral $BEGF$) has area $34$, and we wish to determine the pink area ($\triangle GCD$). First we note that $\triangle AED$ has base $AD$, equal to the side length of square $ABCD$, and also has height equal to the side length of square $ABCD$.
 Thus $\triangle AED$ has area equal to half the area of $ABCD$, or $100$. Triangle $\triangle FEG$ has half the base and half the height of $\triangle AED$, so its area is $\frac12\cdot\frac 12\cdot 100 = 25$.
 Since quadrilateral $BEGF$ can be divided into $\triangle FEG$ and $\triangle FBE$, we know that $\triangle FBE$ has area $34-25=9$. This is half the area of $\triangle ABE$ (which shares an altitude with $\triangle FBE$ and has twice the corresponding base).
 Thus, $\triangle ABE$ has area $18$. Since square $ABCD$ can be divided into triangles $ABE$, $AED$, and $ECD$, we know that the area of $\triangle ECD$ is $200-100-18 = 82$. Finally, $\triangle GCD$ shares an altitude with $\triangle ECD$ and has half the corresponding base, so the area of $\triangle GCD$ is $\frac 12\cdot 82$, or $\boxed{41}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes A B C D E F G :: "real^2"
and area :: "(real^2) \<Rightarrow> (real^2) \<Rightarrow> (real^2) \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "area A B C = 200"
and h1 : "area B E G F = 34"
and h2 : "F = midpoint A E"
and h3 : "G = midpoint D E"
shows  "area G C D = 41"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: Given a set of points A, B, C, D, E, F, G in a plane, if the area of triangle ABC is 200, and the area of quadrilateral BEGF is 34, and F is the midpoint of AE, and G is the midpoint of DE, then find the area of triangle GCD. The answer is 41.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A B C D E F G :: "real^2" and S :: "(real^2) set"
assumes h0 : "B - A = D - C"
and h1 : "C - B = A - D"
and h2 : "A \<bullet> (B - A) = 0"
and h3 : "D \<bullet> (C - D) = 0"
and h4 : "dist A B * dist B C = 200"
and h5 : "E \<in> closed_segment B C"
and h6 : "F = midpoint A E"
and h7 : "G = midpoint D E"
and h8 : "quadrilateral_area B E G F = 34"
shows  "triangle_area G C D = 41"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Square $ABCD$ has area $200$. Point $E$ lies on side $\overline{BC}$. Points $F$ and $G$ are the midpoints of $\overline{AE}$ and $\overline{DE}$, respectively. Given that quadrilateral $BEGF$ has area $34$, what is the area of triangle $GCD$? The final Answer is 41
 ### Proof
 We begin by drawing a diagram: [asy] size(5cm); pair a=(0,1); pair b=(1,1); pair c=(1,0); pair d=(0,0); pair e=(1,.82); pair f=(a+e)/2; pair g=(d+e)/2; fill(b--e--g--f--cycle,gray); fill(g--c--d--cycle,pink);
 dot(a);dot(b);dot(c);dot(d);dot(e);dot(f);dot(g); draw(a--b--c--d--a); draw(a--e--d); draw(e--g--f--b); draw(g--c); label("$A$",a,NW); label("$B$",b,NE); label("$C$",c,SE); label("$D$",d,SW); label("$E$",e,E);
 label("$F$",f,SW); label("$G$",g,NW); [/asy] We know that the gray area above (quadrilateral $BEGF$) has area $34$, and we wish to determine the pink area ($\triangle GCD$). First we note that $\triangle AED$ has base $AD$, equal to the side length of square $ABCD$, and also has height equal to the side length of square $ABCD$.
 Thus $\triangle AED$ has area equal to half the area of $ABCD$, or $100$. Triangle $\triangle FEG$ has half the base and half the height of $\triangle AED$, so its area is $\frac12\cdot\frac 12\cdot 100 = 25$.
 Since quadrilateral $BEGF$ can be divided into $\triangle FEG$ and $\triangle FBE$, we know that $\triangle FBE$ has area $34-25=9$. This is half the area of $\triangle ABE$ (which shares an altitude with $\triangle FBE$ and has twice the corresponding base).
 Thus, $\triangle ABE$ has area $18$. Since square $ABCD$ can be divided into triangles $ABE$, $AED$, and $ECD$, we know that the area of $\triangle ECD$ is $200-100-18 = 82$. Finally, $\triangle GCD$ shares an altitude with $\triangle ECD$ and has half the corresponding base, so the area of $\triangle GCD$ is $\frac 12\cdot 82$, or $\boxed{41}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes A B C D E F G :: "real^2" and S :: "(real^2) set"
assumes h0 : "B - A = D - C"
and h1 : "C - B = A - D"
and h2 : "A \<bullet> (B - A) = 0"
and h3 : "D \<bullet> (C - D) = 0"
and h4 : "dist A B * dist B C = 200"
and h5 : "E \<in> closed_segment B C"
and h6 : "F = midpoint A E"
and h7 : "G = midpoint D E"
and h8 : "quadrilateral_area B E G F = 34"
shows  "triangle_area G C D = 41"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem:
Consider a quadrilateral ABCD, where AB = DC and BC = AD. Also, the angle between AB and BC and the angle between DC and BC are both right angles. The distance between points A and B and points B and C is such that it creates an area of 200 square units.

Now, consider a point E on the line segment BC. Let F be the midpoint of line segment AE and G be the midpoint of line segment DE. If the area of quadrilateral BEGF is 34 square units, find the area of triangle GCD. The final answer is 41 square units.
